channel.title: Victor Villas' Feed
channel.description: The combined feed of my online stuff.

item.title: Finished reading
item.description:
The Burnout Society, 4 out of 10
Read it once; didn't went well. Read it again; less worse but still a drag. The book has an interesting thesis, but the form and writing style are definitely not for me. Maybe if I were pursuing a PhD in philosophy. "How to Do Nothing" by Jenny Odell is the book that I've later found to be the one that scratches the itch I'd imagined "The Burnout Society" should have cauterized.

item.title: Started reading
item.description:
Life After Cars
Got it while attending the authors book tour in Vancouver. Very fun event. Also listened to their podcast episode about the cities visited on tour, interesting stuff.

item.title: Started reading
item.description:
The Burnout Society
Trying to read it again, after a bad experience reading it the first time. Maybe approaching it with different expectations is going to work differently...

item.title: Started reading
item.description:
How to Do Nothing
Reading again because the first time I've "read" it was as an audiobook and I feel like this one deserves a little more attention (and doing-nothingness) to absorb it

item.title: Comment
item.description:
stopped reading The Goblin Emperor
DNF. Doesn't work well as an audiobook for me, maybe too many characters with exotic names to hold in my mind at once.

item.title: Comment
item.description:
How come Waterfront station does not have a bench for me to sit while waiting for someone?

Not even inside Starbucks, just a few inside Subway or A&W üò•

I kind of already imagine answers but come on #Vancouver #Translink

item.title: Comment
item.description:
I was a teenager when I first met someone who did not have dinner everyday - because they were poor - and I will never forget the shock followed by shame.

I was in my 30s when I discovered that some people - who are not poor - simply don‚Äôt have lunch, or have some sort of snack/candy and call it done. What is even going on

item.title: Wants to read
item.description: Technofeudalism

item.title: Comment
item.description:
Get a load of this guy

https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/vance-standard-living-stagnant-immigration-blame-9.6987929

GDP Per Capita is the perfect metric for his type. Deepening inequality means that a few billionaires approaching trillionaire status on the backs of their own working class can create a fiction that somehow the country is working just fine.

While billionaires put cars and penises in orbit and their workers are denied SNAP benefits, we can always celebrate their beautiful GDP per Capita graph. Congratulations.

#CANPoli

item.title: Comment
item.description:
And it solves the issue in yet another relevant way, in that the poorest segment of society gets to die off without care. What we ought to call a policy of extermination: falling off the edges of the economically-valued realm doesn‚Äôt merely make you marginalized, it also sets you up to be erased from the surface of the Earth.

Triple win for the wealthy, double loss for the working class, and a final loss for the poor - death.

#CANPoli

item.title: Comment
item.description:
https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/article-allowing-doctors-to-practise-in-both-public-and-private-systems-solves/

What does walking towards a two-tiered system solve?

It solves this problem of rich people having "too much of a hard time" getting ahead of poor people for medical treatment.

And it solves the issue in a way that the middle class thinks they‚Äôre on the winning side, but in fact they‚Äôre on the losing side, so it ends up solving a second problem: how to further deepen inequality in a way that the mass populace stays under a delusion of fairness.

#CANPoli

item.title: Comment
item.description: And it‚Äôs weirdly human in that regard. You just can‚Äôt ‚Äúmake it better‚Äù by force, despite a lifetime of bad adulting around us making us behave as if that works well for us. (3/3)

item.title: Comment
item.description: No matter how humiliatingly I criticize it or how harsh I am, it‚Äôs not going to stop pretending to know things or jumping to action before understanding the ask. And instead of being conditioned to get harsher, it‚Äôs forcing me to realize that it‚Äôs a waste of time (and tokens, measured in dollars) to say anything other than ‚Äúlet‚Äôs move on to the next part‚Äù or try to explain it more thoroughly from the get go next time. (2/3)

item.title: Comment
item.description: Strange twist of fate in that getting used to pair program with #LLMs is forcing me to become more patient because no matter how much I lash out and make it promise to me it will pay more attention before saying random stuff, I have to accept that it won‚Äôt. (1/3)

item.title: Comment
item.description: #Pluribus looks interesting. But I already know that, like Severance, it‚Äôs going to flood my timelines with bad takes and the most absurd ways to interpret the story. Thank aliens I don‚Äôt share a hive mind with this crowd.

item.title: Comment
item.description:
A new kind of #corporate bullshit has arrived: some of my document writing has been flagged as "off-putting AI generated style", even though I did not use any AI to assist on writing that.

Ironically, I did use an LLM to write some cruft at the end of the doc, but that part wasn't flagged.

Apparently as a non-native speaker my English is not "simple human English". And that's already me self-censoring on the use of em dashes because I had already noticed that ChatGPT overuses them.

item.title: Comment
item.description:
What's the direction The Walrus is looking for? To follow NYT steps as a place where a veneer of journalism can be used to wrap a trojan horse of garbage opinion pieces appeasing questionable people?

We don't need "radically pluralistic" outlets. We need media companies that have uncompromising standards and vet the stuff they're amplifying.

item.title: Comment
item.description:
> No randomized controlled trial has ever shown that masks ‚Äî even good masks properly fitted ‚Äî reduce transmission of respiratory viruses.

> The only explanation for this, that I can think of, is that there was a desperate need for a way of ritualizing the fear that had been generated, and masking provided the needed ritual.

https://nationalpost.com/opinion/david-cayley-cbc-actively-suppressed-credible-covid-dissent

This man is objectively wrong in his reporting of public health matters and thinks that the issue is that #CBC needs to be "radically pluralistic"

item.title: Comment
item.description:
A few weeks ago #TheWalrus came up with a page promoting online gambling. Now they're platforming opinion pieces (https://thewalrus.ca/does-the-cbc-still-speak-for-canada/) that parrot the narrative that CBC is partisan or pro-government propaganda.

To no one‚Äôs surprise, the author of this barely veiled accusation masquerading as book has published nonsensical COVID "dissenter" bullshit during his CBC tenure and is grieving that his shitty journalism was rejected

item.title: Comment
item.description: Nature makes the wrinkliest mushy grapes the sweetest pleasure bombs. Sometimes I doubt myself‚Ä¶ perhaps this one is too far gone? No. Trust the process. Be not afraid of rotten grapes because fortune favours the bold.

item.title: Comment
item.description:
As good as any other day to remember

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paradox_Hotel_Vancouver

opened on February 28, 2017, with Donald Jr., Eric Trump and developer Joo Kim Tiah in attendance [‚Ä¶] met with public protests and a boycott of the ceremony by Mayor Robertson and other local politicians.

On August 28, 2020, the hotel reportedly closed permanently and was filing for bankruptcy. [‚Ä¶] On April 1, 2022 TA Global Berhad reopened the hotel under the brand Paradox Hotel Group and the name Paradox Vancouver.

item.title: Comment
item.description:
ICYMI @viticci I found a funny quirk of AI ubiquity on MacOS:

The Books app generally doesn't facilitate the reader to copy text blurbs from books. But in Tahoe, I can select text from the book and use "Proofread", which opens a small window that does offer the copy option.

LLMs really are the natural enemies of copyright lol

item.title: Comment
item.description:
On the other hand it‚Äôs unfortunate that this normalizes the unwillingness to divert car infrastructure to active mobility. They have some really egregious sharrows and cyclists end up choosing the sidewalk.

In terms of cycling infrastructure and the ability to bring your bike on public transit I do see Vancouver as being ahead. It‚Äôs the ubiquity of cycling and public transit that puts Japan on a different level to me.

item.title: Finished reading
item.description:
Crowd Source
If you live in Vancouver and like birds, this book can be an agreeable companion. I love how niche that is and yet how some of its verses feel so relatable.

item.title: Finished watching
item.description:
Foundation Season 3, 7 out of 10
The production is still the best thing about this show, and the acting is not too shabby but the plot and directing choices are still hit and miss. The Genetic Dynasty remains as the most entertaining blocks of the story, and in this season they are definitely consequential.

item.title: Started watching
item.description: Foundation Season 3

item.title: Finished watching
item.description:
The Martian, 8 out of 10
Watched this one again with Aline. One of the great space movies of the last few years. Can‚Äôt say I‚Äôm a super fan of the crew parts but it‚Äôs the survival storyline that carries the weight here.

Watching this in 2025 highlights interesting artifacts of the movie‚Äôs optimistic times, when the USA is not broadly hated and the president is not tweeting crazy stuff against the Chinese.

item.title: Finished reading
item.description:
11/23: 11 Years / 23 Stories
A wild and different kind of biography. Somewhat alien to me as I was never this deep into the punk scene but still enjoyable, thanks to my teenager metalhead days probably.

item.title: Finished reading
item.description:
Vancouver's Special Guardians, 9 out of 10
An interesting collection of research, from documented facts to hearsay, on these locally famous but otherwise obscure little still creatures. The photography involved is great, it shows that the author is a professional. The book is thin even using a large font so it isn‚Äôt a lot of material but I appreciate the effort in collecting it all in one place.

item.title: Started reading
item.description: Vancouver's Special Guardians

item.title: Started reading
item.description: 11/23: 11 Years / 23 Stories

item.title: Finished watching
item.description:
Murder of Couriers, 10 out of 10
Found this doc/movie by accident and found it so interesting. I ride bicycles, I live in Vancouver, and I caught myself wondering about courier life. This film allowed me to peek behind the reality, awesomeness and toxicity of courier culture in the area.

item.title: Finished reading
item.description:
The Burnout Society, 4 out of 10
Surprisingly uninteresting, quite a disappointment. The book is a social critique written as a philosophy graduate essay: a lot of time is spent on stating analogies to describe modern society defended by other philosophers only to say that the description is inaccurate because so and so. The book has some pillar concepts related to "achievement society" but routinely reaches for unnecessary analogies to immune systems or alternative framings like positivity/negativity. The audience is people who read Heidegger instead of people who do want to understand burnout society.
